docs.title: Welcome to the Go Cook! Online Cookbook
docs.text:
This is a collection of my favorite recipes, accessible from anywhere, like my phone, in the kitchen. This includes recipes collected by my mother Gracia Willis from family and friends, as well as how I actually cook these recipes from my family, as well as new things that I cook now.

Browse by Chapter

  • Breads and Doughs
  • Stocks, Soups, and Stews
  • Breakfast, Eggs, and Dairy
  • Apps, Snacks, and Finger Foods
  • Greens, Salads, and Dressings
  • Cooking Vegetables
  • Pasta, Rice, and Ancient Grains
  • Casseroles, Bakes, and One-Dish Meals
  • Ground Meats
  • Dry-Heat Cooking: Frying and Broiling Proteins
  • Braised and Sauced
  • Roasting: Turkey, Chicken, Prime Rib, and Pork
  • Battered and Fried
  • Ferments and Pickles
  • Desserts
  • Bottom of the Barrel
  • Test Kitchen

How to use this app

Since this website is responsive, you can Add to Home Screen on iOS or Android to treat it like a native cookbook app!

Go Cook! History

docs.title: Go Cook! History
docs.text:
Many of the recipes and the title of this online cookbook come from a cookbook assembled by my mother Gracia Willis around the time of my sister's first wedding. Typeset beautifully in \(\LaTeX\) with cover art by Laura, the print run was around one hundred.

This online version will contain some originals from the print version, sometimes contrasted with a contemporary take on the same recipe, as well as other favorites of mine.

Tom Willis

A Go Cook! print original.

The original preface.

docs.title: Preface
docs.text:
"Go Cook!" is a family cookbook assembled for Tom and Laura Willis. It contains historic family recipies from great-grandmother Stock and her sisters. Many Willis, Stock and Corbin relatives contributed their favorite recipies. Our immediate family recipes cover the period of family favorites from when Tom and Laura were growing up as well as today's choices. Recipies from many friends have also been included.

The title "Go Cook!" is the phrase Tom, as a toddler, used when he was very busy and wanted a parent to leave him along.

Gracia Willis

docs.title: Apps, Snacks, and Finger Foods
docs.text:
Apps, snacks, and finger Foods: appetizers make life better.

  • Barby's Hot Crab Dip
  • Fried Eggplant Strips

docs.title: Barby's Hot Crab Dip
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 10 mins Yields: 4-6 servings

I always loved this dip which would come out at parties. Serve with your favorite crackers.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 8 ounces cream cheese
  • 1 can of king crab, drained
  • ½ teaspoon prepared horseradish
  • 2 tablespoons onion, minced
  • 2 tablespoons milk
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • ½ c almonds, toasted

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Preheat the oven to 375°F
  • Combine all ingredients except almonds and place in a casserole dish.
  • Top with almonds.
  • Cover and bake for 20 minutes.
  • Serve hot, with crackers for dipping and spreading.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
Source

I think Barby was a college friend of Mom's.

My Take

You can take the flavor and kick of this tasty dip up a notch by doubling or tripling the horseradish, onion, and using fresh cracked black pepper. Shake in some crushed red pepper flakes and a little Old Bay for some extra heat.

docs.title: Fried Eggplant Strips
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 10 mins Yields: 4-6 servings

Fried eggplant is a treat with a nice marinara sauce.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 medium egglant, about the volume of a softball
  • 1 egg
  • ½ c milk
  • salt and pepper
  • a sleeve of saltine crackers
  • ½ c olive oil
  • juice of half a lemon
  • optional marinara sauce

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Preheat the oil in a heavy pan or wok over medium-high heat. Do not smoke the oil.
  • Slice unpeeled eggplant lengthwise into 3/8 wide strips.
  • Crush the crackers into crumbs, in a bowl or a zipper-lock bag, then place in a shallow bowl.
  • Mix egg, milk and pepper to taste in a shallow bowl.
  • Dip eggplant into the egg mixture then roll the slices into the cracker crumbs. Set aside without touching each other.
  • Fry the breaded slices in the hot oil in small batches until tender and lightly browned. Set on paper towels when fried.
  • Drizzle lemon juice over the fried eggplant.
  • Serve hot, optionally with warm marinara sauce.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
Source

This is a recipe from my dad, Jim Willis, from around the time he discovered cooking in a wok in the late 70s.

docs.title: Breakfast, Eggs, and Dairy
docs.text:
Some morning things. Also brunch, a more civilized meal.

  • Flag Pancakes

docs.title: Flag Pancakes
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 15 mins Yields: 4 servings

These are the flaggiest pancakes you will ever make. The secret is letting the batter rest! Better with blueberry stars. Originally a breakfast for patriotic occasions like Independence Day, Flag Day, and Memorial Day.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 eggs
  • 1 ½ cups milk
  • 1 tablespoon corn or neutral oil
  • 2 cups Bisquick baking mix
  • red and blue food coloring
  • optional blueberries

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Mix Wet Ingredients: In a separate bowl, whisk the milk and eggs.
  • Slowly add the Bisquick while stirring. Add extra milk by the spoonful if the batter is too thick.
  • Pour a third of the batter into each of two additional bowls.
  • Color one bowl with blue coloring and one with red.

Don't Overmix!

  • Stir until just combined. Lumps are okay! Overmixing makes them tough.
  • Rest: Let the batter sit for 5-10 minutes. You should see bubbles forming.
  • Cook: Heat a skillet over medium heat. Grease with oil. An electric skillet works well.
  • For each pancake, pour the blue field as a rectangle, straightening edges with the spatula as needed. Add optional blueberries as stars.
  • Pour red and white stripes to complete the flag.
  • As soon as bubbles burst in the margins of the pancake, flip to finish. You may need two spatulas.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
More fun

"For additional food fun, pour a shape with one batter and add contrasting dots, stripes, and shapes to the pancake, or around it or fused to it. Make favorite animals, the initials of guests, trains, planes, and automobiles." - Jim Willis

docs.title: Welcome to the Test Kitchen
docs.text:
Experimental recipies. We hope these are good and they may need some tweaks.

  • Welsh Chips and Sauce
  • Kohls Deli German Potato Salad

docs.title: Kohls Deli-Style Hot German Potato Salad (Light Roux, Midwest Deli Version)
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

!!! Welcome to the Test Kitchen. Your mileage may vary."

docs.title: Ingredients (serves \~6)
docs.text:
• 5–6 medium Yukon Gold or red potatoes (about 2 lbs), peeled or scrubbed, cut into 1” cubes
  • 4–5 slices bacon (≈½ lb), diced
  • ½ cup finely diced onion
  • 2 tbsp finely diced celery
  • 2 tbsp all-purpose flour
  • 3 tbsp sugar
  • 1½ tsp salt
  • 1 tsp freshly ground black pepper
  • 1½ tsp celery seed
  • ⅓ cup white or apple cider vinegar
  • ⅓ cup water (or use some potato cooking liquid for extra flavor)

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
1. Cook the potatoes

  2. Place potato cubes in a pot of salted water.

  3. Bring to a boil, simmer 10–12 minutes until just tender but not falling apart. Drain and set aside.

  4. Cook the bacon & aromatics

  5. In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the bacon until crisp. Remove bacon pieces and set aside, leaving the rendered fat in the pan.

  6. Add onions (and celery if using) to the fat. Sauté 3–4 minutes until softened and translucent.

  7. Make the light roux-style sauce

  8. Sprinkle flour over the bacon fat + onions. Stir constantly for 1 minute to cook out the raw taste (this is the light roux).

  9. Add sugar, salt, pepper, and celery seed. Stir.

  10. Gradually whisk in vinegar + water until smooth. Heat gently, stirring, until sauce is slightly thickened but still pourable. Don’t over-thicken — it should lightly coat the potatoes.

  11. Combine with potatoes & bacon

  12. Add cooked potatoes and reserved bacon to the sauce. Gently fold to coat evenly.

  13. Taste and adjust seasoning (vinegar or sugar) as desired.

  14. Serve

  15. Traditional: Serve warm directly from the skillet.

  16. Cold: Let cool to room temperature, then refrigerate — the sauce sets lightly but still clings to the potatoes.

docs.title: Notes / Historical Context
docs.text:
• Light roux: 2 tbsp flour in ½ cup fat + onions is enough to create a silky sauce without heaviness — typical of Milwaukee/St. Louis deli variations.
  • Sugar + vinegar balance: Medium sweet-tang is consistent with Kohl’s and other Midwestern German-American versions.
  • Optional celery: Some vintage community cookbooks from Milwaukee include it; you can omit if you prefer.

Experimental AI recreation of Kohl's deli potato salad https://chatgpt.com/c/69519548-f0c4-832e-a35e-5927ad2721a1#:~:text=Kohl%E2%80%99s%2DStyle%20Hot,with%20cold%20cuts.

TODO:

  • Test the recipe
  • Correct the format

docs.title: Pub-Style Welsh Crisps (Oven-Baked)
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

!!! Welcome to the Test Kitchen. Your mileage may vary."

These are hand-cut pub crisps, thin like American potato chips but cooked in a way that allows occasional sticking and unevenness. Crisp edges, tender centers. Rustic by design.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1½ lb Yukon Gold or red potatoes
  • 2 tbsp olive oil
  • ¾ tsp kosher salt
  • Freshly ground black pepper

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text:
1. Heat oven to 425°F (220°C).
  2. Slice potatoes 1.5–2 mm thick using a mandoline or slicer. Leave skins on.
  3. Optional: soak slices in cold water 10 minutes max. Drain and dry thoroughly.
  4. Toss slices gently with olive oil and salt.

docs.title: Cooking
docs.text:
1. Line a baking sheet with parchment.
  2. Arrange potato slices in a mostly single layer. Overlap is acceptable.
  3. Bake 15 minutes.
  4. Flip gently, keeping any fused slices intact.
  5. Bake another 10–15 minutes, until deeply golden and crisp at the edges.

docs.title: Finish & Serve
docs.text:
• Sprinkle lightly with salt and pepper.
  • Serve hot, alongside Welsh rarebit or as a base for dipping.

docs.title: Welsh Rarebit (Mustard-Forward, Traditional)
docs.text: This is a proper rarebit: sharp, savory, mustard-led, and restrained. No beer foaminess, no spice heat, no cheese overload. Designed to sit comfortably with crisps or toast.

docs.title: Sauce Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 tbsp butter
  • 1 tbsp all-purpose flour
  • ½ cup milk
  • ¾ cup sharp white cheddar, finely grated
  • 1½ tsp Dijon mustard
  • ½ tsp dry mustard powder
  • 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce
  • Black pepper, to taste
  • 1 tsp malt vinegar or lemon juice

docs.title: Sauce Preparation
docs.text:
1. Melt butter in a small saucepan over medium-low heat.
  2. Whisk in flour and cook 1–2 minutes, just until lightly blond.
  3. Gradually whisk in milk until smooth.
  4. Cook gently until slightly thickened.

docs.title: Finish the Sauce
docs.text:
1. Reduce heat to low.
  2. Stir in Dijon, dry mustard, Worcestershire, and pepper.
  3. Add cheese in small handfuls, stirring just until melted.
  4. Taste and adjust with a few drops of vinegar if needed.

Do not boil.

docs.title: Serve
docs.text:
• Spoon over toasted bread and broil briefly until lightly blistered, or
  • Serve warm as a dip alongside pub crisps.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The mustard should be noticeable but not aggressive.
  • The sauce should be pourable, not spoon-stiff.
  • This rarebit is savory, not creamy-sweet.

If you insist on deep frying, use a neutral oil (peanut, canola, or sunflower) with a high smoke point. Not olive oil.

Preparation as above Remember, drain and dry very thoroughly with towels: moisture is the enemy of crispness and safety.

Frying

  • Heat oil to 350°F (175°C).
  • Fry potatoes in small batches. Do not overcrowd. Allow some slices to touch and overlap.
  • Fry 2–3 minutes, stirring gently once or twice, until:
  • Edges are golden
  • Centers are set but not brittle

Draining & Seasoning

Remove crisps with a spider or slotted spoon. Drain briefly on a rack or paper towels. Season immediately with salt and black pepper.

docs.title: Ground Meats
docs.text:
Lunch is good food.

  • Mom's Sloppy Joes
  • Mom's Meatloaf

docs.title: Mom's Meatloaf
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 60 mins Yields: 4-6 servings

This is the meatloaf of my childhood. Like any good meatloaf recipe, leftovers are great for sandwiches the next day.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 pound ground beef
  • 1 ½ slices bread, torn into small pieces
  • ½ cups milk
  • 1 egg, beaten
  • 2 tablespoons dried minced onion
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • ⅛ teaspoon pepper
  • ⅛ teaspoon dry mustard
  • ⅛ celery salt
  • ⅛ garlic salt
  • 1 ½ teaspoons Worcestershire sauce
  • ketchup
  • optional, 3 hard cooked eggs, peeled

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Preheat oven to 350°F.
  • Mix ground beef, bread and milk.
  • Add the beaten egg, spices, and Worcestershire sauce.
  • Shape into a load, in a loaf pan.
  • If desired, hide the peeled hard cooked eggs in the center of the loaf.
  • Spread ketchup over the top of the loaf.
  • Bake for 1 hour.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
My Take

I don't think I have ever cooked this recipe with the small amounts of spices called for: I always use a lot more. Also, I never have celery salt or garlic salt, so I use celery seed and garlic powder when I cook this.

My kids don't seem to go for the tucked eggs, but if you want that authentic Sixties style, the eggs and ketchup bring it on.

docs.title: Mom's Sloppy Joes
docs.text:
Kitchen Mode

Keep screen on

iOS users: To keep your screen on while cooking, set Auto-Lock → Never in Settings → Display & Brightness.

A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 30 mins Yields: 6 servings

We ate a lot of this as a kid. I didn't know that Sloppy Joes normally have bell peppers until I left home.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 ½ pounds ground beef
  • 1 onion, chopped
  • ½ c ketchup
  • 1 tablespoon yellow mustard
  • 1 can chicken gumbo soup
  • 1 cup water
  • 3-ounce can mushroom bits and pieces, drained
  • salt and pepper
  • optional, 6 sandwich rolls, toasted

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Cook the beef and onions together until lightly browned, breaking up the meat.
  • Add the remaining ingredients, except rolls.
  • Cover, bring to a boil, drop temperature to simmer about 30 minutes.
  • Serve on toasted rolls or other bread.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
Source

This is a recipe my mom Gracia Willis made a lot when we were little kids. I don't remember using the mushrooms when I made it as a later as a teen.

docs.title: Stocks, Soups, and Stews
docs.text:
Good food.

  • Willie's Chili
  • Oyster Stew

docs.title: Oyster Stew
docs.text:
A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 20 mins Yields: 4 servings.

This was a New Year's Eve treat in my childhood, often prepared by my dad.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 tablespoons flour
  • 1 ½ teaspoons salt
  • 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce
  • dash Tabasco sauce
  • 2 tablespoons water
  • 1 pint oysters, with the liquor
  • ¼ cup margarine
  • 1 quart milk, scalded
  • pats of margarine
  • oyster, or other, crackers

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Blend flour, seasonings, and water in a soup kettle.
  • Add undrained oysters and margarine.
  • Simmer over very low heat for 3-4 minutes until the edges of the oysters begin to curl, stirring gently.
  • Add very hot milk, remove from heat and cover.
  • Let stand for 15 minutes.
  • Reheat briefly.
  • Serve in bowls and top with margarine pats.
  • Serve with oyster crackers.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
My Take

I always increase the Worcestershire in almost all the old family recipes and this is no exception. Also, a dash of Tabasco? Hah. Consider substituting Crystal, Louisiana, or Franks for Tabasco, and shake it in there. Also, I do not recall the last time I used margarine, so use butter. For extra depth, add some Old Bay spice powder in the first step.

docs.title: Stayabed Stew
docs.text:
A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 10 mins Cook: 5 hours Yields: 4 to6 servings.

This was a common cold weather dinner I learned as a tween. My first dump-and-bake.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 pounds beef stew meat, cubed
  • 1 cup sliced carrots
  • 2 onions, chopped
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • dash of pepper
  • 1 can cream of tomato soup
  • ½ soup can of water
  • 1 big potato, sliced
  • piece of bay leaf

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Preheat oven to 275°F.
  • Mix all ingredients in a lidded casserole.
  • Cover and bake for 5 hours.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
Source

This was my mother's favorite recipe from Peg Brakken's classic "I Hate to Cook Book" from 1960.

My Take

The 5 hour cooking time allows a wonderful browning of the beef chunks from the Maillard Reaction, while giving time to literally go back to bed while it cooks.

Who can find cream of tomato soup anymore, so just use regular condensed tomato soup.

docs.title: Willie's Chili
docs.text:
A Go Cook! print original.

Prep: 20 mins Cook: 120 mins Yields: Serves 4, twice.

This is the chili of my childhood, often prepared by my dad. This is a vastly scaled-down version of a VA Hospital recipe that fed 1100 people at a time.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 pounds ground beef
  • 2 medium yellow onions, peeled and sliced
  • 2 or 3 teaspoons chili powder
  • 2 one pound cans of chili beans (use 15oz cans)
  • 2 one pound cans of kidney beans (use 15oz cans), rinsed
  • 2 28 ounce cans of stewed whole tomatoes or equivalent fresh tomatoes, including green tomatoes

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Brown the ground beef in a stew pot in the presence of the chili powder.
  • Add the onions and cook until tender.
  • Add the kidney beans and chili beans.
  • Add the tomatoes.
  • Fill both chili bean cans with water and add to the pot. If desired, add more water.
  • Simmer, stirring, for at least 2 hours.

  • Serve with corn bread.

  • Add the beaten egg, spices, and Worcestershire sauce.

  • Shape into a load, in a loaf pan.
  • If desired, hide the peeled hard cooked eggs in the center of the loaf.
  • Spread ketchup over the top of the loaf.
  • Bake for 1 hour.

docs.title: Chef's Notes
docs.text:
My Take

I often take this recipe in other directions, but it is a solid Midwestern chili that just works. Even better the next day.

Source

My grandfather Henry Willis would make chili for the masses when he was a cook at the VA hospital in Knoxville, Iowa. He taught this recipe my dad Jim in 1953 so he would know how to cook something when he got to college.
